<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">A reporting issue has arisen regarding the
application of certain provisions of SFAS&nbsp;No.&nbsp;141 and
SFAS&nbsp;No.&nbsp;142 to companies in the extractive
industries, including oil and natural gas companies. The issue
is whether SFAS&nbsp;No.&nbsp;142 requires registrants to
classify the costs of mineral rights associated with extracting
oil and natural gas as intangible assets in the balance sheet,
apart from other capitalized oil and natural gas property costs,
and to provide specific footnote disclosures. Historically, we
have included the costs of mineral/drilling rights associated
with extracting oil and natural gas as tangible assets and as a
component of oil and natural gas properties. If it is ultimately
determined that SFAS&nbsp;No.&nbsp;142 requires oil
</FONT>

<P align="center"><FONT size="2">F-11
</FONT>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV align="center">
<B><FONT size="2">WESTPORT RESOURCES CORPORATION</FONT></B>
</DIV>

<P align="center">
<B><FONT size="2">NOTES TO CONSOLIDATED
FINANCIAL&nbsp;STATEMENTS&nbsp;&#151;&nbsp;(Continued)</FONT></B>

<P align="left">
<FONT size="2">and natural as companies to classify costs of
mineral rights associated with extracting oil and natural gas as
a separate intangible assets line item on the balance sheet, we
would be required to reclassify the amounts as follows:
</FONT>

<CENTER>
<TABLE width="80%" align="center" cellspacing="0" cellpadding="0" border="0">

<TR>
    <TD width="3%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="3%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="58%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="3%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="7%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="1%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="7%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="3%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="7%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="1%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="7%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD colspan="3"></TD>
    <TD></TD>
    <TD colspan="7"></TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD colspan="3"></TD>
    <TD></TD>
    <TD colspan="6" align="center" nowrap><B><FONT size="1">December&nbsp;31,</FONT></B></TD><TD></TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD colspan="3"></TD>
    <TD></TD>
    <TD colspan="6" align="center" nowrap><HR size="1" noshade></TD><TD></TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD colspan="3"></TD>
    <TD></TD>
    <TD colspan="2" align="center" nowrap><B><FONT size="1">2003</FONT></B></TD><TD></TD>
    <TD></TD>
    <TD colspan="2" align="center" nowrap><B><FONT size="1">2002</FONT></B></TD><TD></TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD colspan="3"></TD>
    <TD></TD>
    <TD colspan="2" align="center" nowrap><HR size="1" noshade></TD><TD></TD>
    <TD></TD>
    <TD colspan="2" align="center" nowrap><HR size="1" noshade></TD><TD></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="bottom" bgcolor="#EEEEEE">
    <TD colspan="3" align="left" valign="top">
    <DIV style="margin-left:10px; text-indent:-10px">
    <FONT size="2">Intangible Assets:
    </FONT></DIV>
    </TD>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD colspan="2" align="left" valign="top">

    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>

</CENTER>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">Westport&#146;s cash flows and results of
operations would not be affected since such intangible assets
would continue to be depleted and assessed for impairment in
accordance with SFAS&nbsp;No.&nbsp;144. Further, the Company
does not believe the classification of the costs of mineral
rights associated with extracting oil and natural gas as
intangible assets would have any impact on its compliance with
covenants under its debt agreements.
</FONT>

<DIV>&nbsp;</DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0">

<TR>
    <TD width="3%"></TD>
    <TD width="97%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD></TD>
    <TD>
    <B><I><FONT size="2">Capitalized Interest</FONT></I></B></TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">The Company capitalizes interest on expenditures
of significant exploration and development projects while
activities are in progress to bring the assets to their intended
use. The Company began capitalizing interest in 2002 during
which $45,000 was capitalized. In 2003, $144,000 was capitalized.
</FONT>

<DIV>&nbsp;</DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0">

<TR>
    <TD width="3%"></TD>
    <TD width="97%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD></TD>
    <TD>
    <B><I><FONT size="2">Principles of Consolidation</FONT></I></B></TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">The consolidated financial statements include the
accounts of the Company and its wholly owned subsidiaries. All
significant intercompany accounts and transactions have been
eliminated in the consolidation.
</FONT>

<DIV>&nbsp;</DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0">

<TR>
    <TD width="3%"></TD>
    <TD width="97%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD></TD>
    <TD>
    <B><I><FONT size="2">Earnings (Loss) per Common
    Share</FONT></I></B></TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">The Company follows the provisions of
SFAS&nbsp;No.&nbsp;128, &#147;Earnings Per Share.&#148; Basic
earnings per share is computed based on the weighted average
number of common shares outstanding. Diluted earnings per share
is computed based on the weighted average number of common
shares outstanding adjusted for the incremental shares
attributed to outstanding options and warrants to purchase
common stock. All options to purchase common shares were
excluded from the computation of diluted earnings per share in
2002 because they were antidilutive as a result of the
Company&#146;s net loss in that year. Dilutive securities of the
Company consist entirely of outstanding options to purchase the
Company&#146;s common stock. The Company&#146;s
6&nbsp;1/2%&nbsp;convertible preferred stock was antidilutive
for the period it has been outstanding.
</FONT>

<DIV>&nbsp;</DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0">

<TR>
    <TD width="3%"></TD>
    <TD width="97%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD></TD>
    <TD>
    <B><I><FONT size="2">Consolidated Statements of Cash
    Flows</FONT></I></B></TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">For purposes of the Statements of Cash Flows, the
costs of exploratory dry holes are included in cash flows from
investing activities.
</FONT>

<DIV>&nbsp;</DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0">

<TR>
    <TD width="3%"></TD>
    <TD width="97%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD></TD>
    <TD>
    <B><I><FONT size="2">Income Taxes</FONT></I></B></TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">The Company computes income taxes in accordance
with SFAS&nbsp;No.&nbsp;109, &#147;Accounting for Income
Taxes.&#148; SFAS&nbsp;No.&nbsp;109 requires an asset and
liability approach which results in the recognition of deferred
</FONT>

<P align="center"><FONT size="2">F-12
</FONT>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV align="center">
<B><FONT size="2">WESTPORT RESOURCES CORPORATION</FONT></B>
</DIV>

<P align="center">
<B><FONT size="2">NOTES TO CONSOLIDATED
FINANCIAL&nbsp;STATEMENTS&nbsp;&#151;&nbsp;(Continued)</FONT></B>

<P align="left">
<FONT size="2">tax liabilities and assets for the expected
future tax consequences of temporary differences between the
carrying amounts and the tax basis of those assets and
liabilities. SFAS&nbsp;No.&nbsp;109 also requires the recording
of a valuation allowance if it is more likely than not that some
portion or all of a deferred tax asset will not be realized.
</FONT>

<DIV>&nbsp;</DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0">

<TR>
    <TD width="3%"></TD>
    <TD width="97%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD></TD>
    <TD>
    <B><I><FONT size="2">Building, Office Furniture and Equipment
    and Leasehold Improvements</FONT></I></B></TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">Building, office furniture and equipment are
stated at cost and are depreciated using the straight-line
method over their estimated useful lives of three to
20&nbsp;years. Leasehold improvements are amortized over the
life of the related lease. Maintenance and repairs are charged
to expense as incurred. Gains or losses on dispositions of
office furniture and equipment are included in operations.
</FONT>

<DIV>&nbsp;</DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0">

<TR>
    <TD width="3%"></TD>
    <TD width="97%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD></TD>
    <TD>
    <B><I><FONT size="2">Derivative Activity</FONT></I></B></TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">The Company periodically enters into commodity
derivative contracts and fixed-price physical contracts to
manage its exposure to oil and natural gas price volatility. The
Company primarily utilizes future contracts, swaps or options
which are generally placed with major financial institutions or
with counterparties of high credit quality that the Company
believes are minimal credit risks. The oil and natural gas
reference prices of these commodity derivatives contracts are
based upon crude oil and natural gas futures which have a high
degree of historical correlation with actual prices received by
the Company.
</FONT>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">On January&nbsp;1, 2001, the Company adopted
SFAS&nbsp;No.&nbsp;133, &#147;Accounting for Derivative
Instruments and Hedging Activities.&#148; Under
SFAS&nbsp;No.&nbsp;133 all derivative instruments are recorded
on the balance sheet at fair value. Changes in the
derivative&#146;s fair value are recognized currently in
earnings unless specific hedge accounting criteria are met. For
qualifying cash flow hedges, the gain or loss on the derivative
is deferred in accumulated other comprehensive income (loss) to
the extent the hedge is effective. For qualifying fair value
hedges, the gain or loss on the derivative is offset by related
results of the hedged item in the income statement. Gains and
losses on hedging instruments included in accumulated other
comprehensive income (loss) are reclassified to oil and natural
gas sales revenue in the period that the related production is
delivered. Derivative contracts that do not qualify for hedge
accounting treatment are recorded as derivative assets and
liabilities at fair value in the consolidated balance sheet, and
the associated unrealized gains and losses are recorded as
current expense or income in the consolidated statement of
operations. While such derivative contracts do not qualify for
hedge accounting, management believes these contracts can be
utilized as an effective component of CPRM activities to help
reduce volatility of expected revenues. See Notes&nbsp;3
and&nbsp;7.
</FONT>

<DIV>&nbsp;</DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0">

<TR>
    <TD width="3%"></TD>
    <TD width="97%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD></TD>
    <TD>
    <B><I><FONT size="2">Stock Compensation Expense</FONT></I></B></TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">Stock compensation expense consists of noncash
charges resulting from the application of the provisions of FASB
Interpretation No.&nbsp;44 to certain stock options granted to
employees and issuance of restricted stock to certain employees.
Under Interpretation No.&nbsp;44 the Company is required to
measure compensation cost on stock options that are considered
to be variable awards until the date of exercise, forfeiture or
expiration of such options. Compensation cost is measured for
the amount of any increases in the Company stock price and
recognized over the remaining vesting period of the options. Any
decrease in the Company stock price will be recognized as a
decrease in compensation cost limited to the amount of
compensation cost previously recognized as a result of an
increase in the Company stock price.
</FONT>

<DIV>&nbsp;</DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0">

<TR>
    <TD width="3%"></TD>
    <TD width="97%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD></TD>
    <TD>
    <B><I><FONT size="2">Fair Value of Financial
    Instruments</FONT></I></B></TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">The carrying amounts of the Company&#146;s cash,
accounts receivable, accounts payable and accrued expenses
approximate fair value due to the short-term maturities of these
assets and liabilities. The carrying amount of the
Company&#146;s long-term debt approximates fair value based on
the variable borrowing
</FONT>

<P align="center"><FONT size="2">F-13
</FONT>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV align="center">
<B><FONT size="2">WESTPORT RESOURCES CORPORATION</FONT></B>
</DIV>

<P align="center">
<B><FONT size="2">NOTES TO CONSOLIDATED
FINANCIAL&nbsp;STATEMENTS&nbsp;&#151;&nbsp;(Continued)</FONT></B>

<P align="left">
<FONT size="2">rate of the credit facility and the interest rate
swaps in place that hedge the fair value of a portion of the
senior subordinated notes.
</FONT>

<DIV>&nbsp;</DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0">

<TR>
    <TD width="3%"></TD>
    <TD width="97%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD></TD>
    <TD>
    <B><I><FONT size="2">Use of Estimates</FONT></I></B></TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">The preparation of consolidated financial
statements in conformity with generally accepted accounting
principles in the United States of America requires management
to make estimates and assumptions that affect the reported
amounts of assets and liabilities and disclosure of contingent
assets and liabilities at the date of the consolidated financial
statements and the reported amounts of revenues and expenses
during the reporting period. Actual results could differ from
those estimates.
</FONT>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">The Company&#146;s consolidated financial
statements are based on a number of significant estimates
including oil and natural gas reserve quantities which are the
basis for the calculation of depletion, impairment of oil and
natural gas properties and impairment of goodwill.
</FONT>

<DIV>&nbsp;</DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0">

<TR>
    <TD width="3%"></TD>
    <TD width="97%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD></TD>
    <TD>
    <B><I><FONT size="2">Comprehensive Income</FONT></I></B></TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">The Company follows the provisions of
SFAS&nbsp;No.&nbsp;130, &#147;Reporting Comprehensive
Income,&#148; which establishes standards for reporting and
display of comprehensive income and its components in a full set
of general-purpose financial statements. In addition to net
income, comprehensive income includes all changes in equity
during a period, except those resulting from investments and
distributions to owners.
</FONT>

<DIV>&nbsp;</DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0">

<TR>
    <TD width="3%"></TD>
    <TD width="97%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD></TD>
    <TD>
    <B><I><FONT size="2">Recent Accounting
    Pronouncements</FONT></I></B></TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">In June 2001, the FASB issued
SFAS&nbsp;No.&nbsp;143, &#147;Accounting for Asset Retirement
Obligations.&#148; SFAS&nbsp;No.&nbsp;143 requires entities to
record the fair value of liabilities for retirement obligations
of acquired assets. SFAS&nbsp;No.&nbsp;143 is effective for
fiscal years beginning after June&nbsp;15, 2002. The Company
adopted SFAS&nbsp;No.&nbsp;143 on January&nbsp;1, 2003 and
recorded a cumulative effect of a change in accounting principle
on prior years of $3.4&nbsp;million, net of tax effects, related
to the depreciation and accretion expense that would have been
reported had the fair value of the asset retirement obligations,
and corresponding increase in the carrying amount of the related
long-lived assets, been recorded when incurred. The
Company&#146;s asset retirement obligations arise from the
plugging and abandonment liabilities for its oil and gas wells
and offshore platform facilities. On January&nbsp;1, 2003, the
Company also recorded $58.7&nbsp;million of asset retirement
obligations (using a 7.6% discount rate), an increase in the
carrying amount of its oil and gas properties of
$49.6&nbsp;million and a decrease to accumulated depreciation of
$3.8&nbsp;million. Changes to the Company&#146;s asset
retirement obligations from January&nbsp;1 to December&nbsp;31
of 2003 are presented below:
</FONT>

<P align="left">
<FONT size="2">The Company&#146;s current and long-term asset
retirement obligations are included in current asset retirement
obligation and long-term asset retirement obligation,
respectively, on the accompanying December&nbsp;31, 2003
consolidated balance sheet.
</FONT>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">In April 2002, the FASB issued
SFAS&nbsp;No.&nbsp;145, &#147;Rescission of FASB Statements
No.&nbsp;4, 44 and 64, Amendment of FASB Statement No.&nbsp;13
and Technical Corrections.&#148; Prior to the adoption of the
provisions of SFAS&nbsp;No.&nbsp;145, GAAP required that gains
or losses on the early extinguishment of debt be classified in a
company&#146;s periodic consolidated statements of operations as
extraordinary gains or losses, net of associated income taxes,
below the determination of income or loss from continuing
operations. SFAS&nbsp;No.&nbsp;145 changed GAAP to require,
except in the case of events or transactions of a highly unusual
and infrequent nature, gains or losses from the early
extinguishment of debt be classified as components of a
company&#146;s income or loss from continuing operations. The
Company adopted the provisions of SFAS&nbsp;No.&nbsp;145 on
January&nbsp;1, 2003. In May 2003, the Company recorded a
$0.9&nbsp;million loss in connection with the early
extinguishment of debt in 2003.
</FONT>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">In June 2002, the FASB issued
SFAS&nbsp;No.&nbsp;146, &#147;Accounting for Costs Associated
with Exit or Disposal Activities.&#148; SFAS&nbsp;No.&nbsp;146
requires that a liability for a cost associated with an exit or
disposal activity be recognized and measured initially at fair
value only when the liability is incurred.
SFAS&nbsp;No.&nbsp;146 is effective for exit or disposal
activities that are initiated after December&nbsp;31, 2002. The
Company adopted SFAS&nbsp;No.&nbsp;146 on January&nbsp;1, 2003.
The adoption of SFAS&nbsp;No.&nbsp;146 has not had an effect on
the Company&#146;s financial position or results of operations.
</FONT>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">In December 2002, the FASB issued
SFAS&nbsp;No.&nbsp;148, &#147;Accounting for Stock-based
Compensation-Transition and Disclosure.&#148; SFAS&nbsp;148
amended FASB Statement No.&nbsp;123, &#147;Accounting for
Stock-Based Compensation&#148; to provide alternative methods of
transition for a voluntary change to the fair-value based method
of accounting for stock-based employee compensation. In
addition, this Statement amends the disclosure requirements of
Statement&nbsp;123 to require prominent disclosures in both
annual and interim financial statements about the method of
accounting for stock-based employee compensation and the effect
of the method used on the reported results. The provisions of
SFAS&nbsp;148 has no material impact on us, as we do not plan to
adopt the fair-value method of accounting for stock options at
the current time. We have included the required disclosures in
Note&nbsp;9 to the Consolidated Financial Statements.
</FONT>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">In November 2002, the FASB issued Financial
Interpretation No.&nbsp;45, &#147;Guarantor&#146;s Accounting
and Disclosure Requirements for Guarantees, Including Indirect
Guarantees of Indebtedness of Others&nbsp;&#151; an
</FONT>

<P align="center"><FONT size="2">F-15
</FONT>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV align="center">
<B><FONT size="2">WESTPORT RESOURCES CORPORATION</FONT></B>
</DIV>

<P align="center">
<B><FONT size="2">NOTES TO CONSOLIDATED
FINANCIAL&nbsp;STATEMENTS&nbsp;&#151;&nbsp;(Continued)</FONT></B>

<P align="left">
<FONT size="2">interpretation of FASB Statements No.&nbsp;5, 57,
and 107 and rescission of FASB Interpretation No.&nbsp;34&#148;
(FIN&nbsp;45). FIN&nbsp;45 elaborates on the disclosures to be
made by a guarantor in its interim and annual financial
statements about its obligations under certain guarantees that
it has issued. It also clarifies that a guarantor is required to
recognize, at the inception of a guarantee, a liability for the
fair value of the obligation undertaken in issuing the
guarantee. The initial recognition and initial measurement
provisions of FIN&nbsp;45 are applicable on a prospective basis
to guarantees issued or modified after December&nbsp;31, 2002,
irrespective of the guarantor&#146;s fiscal year-end. The
disclosure requirements are effective for financial statements
of interim or annual periods ending after December&nbsp;15,
2002. The adoption of FIN&nbsp;45 has not had any effect on the
Company&#146;s financial position or results of operations.
</FONT>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">In January 2003, the FASB issued Financial
Interpretation No.&nbsp;46, &#147;Consolidation of Variable
Interest Entities&nbsp;&#151; an interpretation of ARB
No.&nbsp;51&#148; (FIN&nbsp;46). FIN&nbsp;46 is an
interpretation of Accounting Research Bulletin&nbsp;51,
&#147;Consolidated Financial Statements&#148;, and addresses
consolidation by business enterprises of variable interest
entities (VIE&#146;s). The primary objective of the
Interpretation is to provide guidance on the identification of,
and financial reporting for, entities over which control is
achieved through means other than voting rights; such entities
are known as VIE&#146;s. FIN&nbsp;46 requires an enterprise to
consolidate a VIE if that enterprise has a variable interest
that will absorb a majority of the entity&#146;s expected losses
if they occur, receive a majority of the entity&#146;s expected
residual returns if they occur, or both. An enterprise shall
consider the rights and obligations conveyed by its variable
interests in making this determination. This guidance applies
immediately to variable interest entities created after
January&nbsp;31, 2003, and to variable interest entities in
which an enterprise obtains an interest after that date. It
applies in the first fiscal year or interim period beginning
after June&nbsp;15, 2003, to variable interest entities in which
an enterprise holds a variable interest that it acquired before
February&nbsp;1, 2003. At this time, the Company does not have a
VIE.
</FONT>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">In April 2003, FASB issued
SFAS&nbsp;No.&nbsp;149, &#147;Amendment of Statement&nbsp;133 on
Derivative Instruments and Hedging Activities.&#148;
SFAS&nbsp;No.&nbsp;149 amends and clarifies financial accounting
and reporting for derivative instruments, including certain
derivative instruments embedded in other contracts and for
hedging activities under SFAS&nbsp;No.&nbsp;133,
&#147;Accounting for Derivative Instruments and Hedging
Activities.&#148; SFAS&nbsp;No.&nbsp;149 is effective for
contracts entered into or modified after June&nbsp;30, 2003 and
for hedging relationships designated after June&nbsp;30, 2003.
The Company adopted SFAS&nbsp;No.&nbsp;149 on July&nbsp;1, 2003
and it has not had a material impact on its financial condition
and results of operations.
</FONT>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">In May 2003, the FASB issued
SFAS&nbsp;No.&nbsp;150, &#147;Accounting for Certain Financial
Instruments with Characteristics of Both Liabilities and
Equity.&#148; SFAS&nbsp;No.&nbsp;150 changes the accounting for
certain financial instruments that, under previous guidance,
issuers could account for as equity. FASB No.&nbsp;150 requires
that those instruments be classified as liabilities in
statements of financial position. SFAS&nbsp;No.&nbsp;150 is
effective for financial instruments entered into or modified
after May&nbsp;31, 2003, and otherwise is effective at the
beginning of the first interim period beginning after
June&nbsp;15, 2003. The adoption of SFAS&nbsp;No.&nbsp;150 has
not had any effect on the Company&#146;s financial position or
results of operations.
</FONT>

<P align="center"><FONT size="2">F-16
</FONT>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;

oil and gas properties located in South Texas, also referred to
as the South Texas Acquisition, for a total cash purchase price
of approximately $341.7&nbsp;million, which includes certain
purchase price adjustments, allocated as follows (in thousands):

<TR valign="top">

    <TD>
    <B><I><FONT size="2">Uinta Basin Acquisition</FONT></I></B></TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">On December&nbsp;17, 2002, effective as of
June&nbsp;1, 2002, the Company acquired producing properties,
undeveloped leaseholds, gathering and compression facilities and
other related assets in the Greater Natural Buttes area of
Uintah County, Utah from affiliates of El&nbsp;Paso Corporation
for approximately $507.2&nbsp;million (the &#147;Uinta Basin
Acquisition&#148;), which includes certain purchase price
adjustments. The Company&#146;s newly formed Western Division is
comprised substantially of these properties.
</FONT>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">The total purchase price of $507.2&nbsp;million
was allocated as follows (in thousands):
</FONT>

<CENTER>
<TABLE width="70%" align="center" cellspacing="0" cellpadding="0" border="0">

<TR>
    <TD width="3%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="3%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="80%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="3%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="5%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="1%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="5%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="bottom" bgcolor="#EEEEEE">
    <TD colspan="3" align="left" valign="top">
    <DIV style="margin-left:10px; text-indent:-10px">
    <FONT size="2">Allocation of purchase price:
    </FONT></DIV>
    </TD>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
</TR>

<TR>

<TR>
    <TD width="4%"></TD>
    <TD width="96%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD><B><FONT size="2">3.</FONT></B></TD>
    <TD>
    <B><FONT size="2">Commodity Derivative Instruments and Hedging
    Activities</FONT></B></TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">The Company periodically enters into commodity
price risk management (&#147;CPRM&#148;) transactions to manage
its exposure to oil and gas price volatility. CPRM transactions
may take the form of futures contracts, swaps or options. All
CPRM data is presented in accordance with requirements of
SFAS&nbsp;No.&nbsp;133 which the Company adopted on
January&nbsp;1, 2001. Accordingly, unrealized gains and losses
related to the change in fair market value of derivative
contracts which qualify and are designated as cash flow hedges
are recorded as other comprehensive income or loss and such
amounts are reclassified to oil and gas sales revenues as the
associated production occurs. Derivative contracts that do not
qualify for hedge accounting treatment are recorded as
derivative assets and liabilities at market value in the
consolidated balance sheet, and the associated unrealized gains
and losses are recorded as current expense or income in the
consolidated statement of operations. While such derivative
contracts do not qualify for hedge accounting, management
believes these contracts can be utilized as an effective
component of CPRM activities.
</FONT>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">Upon adoption of SFAS&nbsp;No.&nbsp;133 on
January&nbsp;1, 2001, the Company recorded a derivative
liability of approximately $4.7&nbsp;million for the fair market
value of its derivative instruments designated as cash flow
hedges and a corresponding loss of approximately
$3.1&nbsp;million (net of tax effect of $1.6&nbsp;million) as a
cumulative effect of a change in accounting principle in other
comprehensive income. For the years ended December&nbsp;31,
2003, 2002 and 2001 the Company reclassified approximately
$102.4&nbsp;million, $1.3&nbsp;million of hedging losses and
$2.1&nbsp;million of hedging gains out of accumulated other
comprehensive income into oil and gas sales revenues,
respectively. The hedging losses and gains reclassified to
revenues include cash losses of $105.4&nbsp;million,
$8.2&nbsp;million and $4.5&nbsp;million for the years ended
December&nbsp;31, 2003, 2002 and 2001, respectively. As of
December&nbsp;31, 2003, the Company expects to reclassify
approximately $101.6&nbsp;million of loss into earnings from
accumulated other comprehensive income during 2004.
</FONT>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">For the years ended December&nbsp;31, 2003, 2002
and 2001, the Company recorded non-hedge CPRM settlements of
$2.7&nbsp;million, $0.8&nbsp;million and $15.3&nbsp;million,
respectively. The non-hedge CPRM settlements reflect cash
settlements of ($1.0)&nbsp;million, ($2.9)&nbsp;million and
$3.6&nbsp;million for the years ended December&nbsp;31, 2003,
2002 and 2001, respectively.
</FONT>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">For the years ended December&nbsp;31, 2003, 2002
and 2001, the Company recorded unrealized non-hedge change in
fair value of derivatives of $9.5&nbsp;million which included
$2.9&nbsp;million ineffectiveness loss, ($26.7) which included a
$0.1&nbsp;million ineffectiveness loss and $14.3&nbsp;million
with no ineffectiveness, respectively. The majority,
$18.2&nbsp;million, of the non-hedge loss in fair value of
derivatives for 2002 was related to derivative contracts entered
into in anticipation of the expected production acquired in the
Uinta Basin Acquisition. Upon closing of the transaction the
derivative contracts qualified for hedge accounting treatment.
</FONT>

<P align="center"><FONT size="2">F-18
</FONT>

    <TD width="3%"></TD>
    <TD width="1%"></TD>
    <TD width="96%"></TD>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&#149;&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD align="left">
    <FONT size="2">4.8&nbsp;Mmbbls of oil and 71.3&nbsp;Bcf of
    natural gas subject to CPRM contracts for 2004. Of these
    contracts, all of the oil and 60.3&nbsp;Bcf of the natural gas
    contracts are subject to weighted average floor prices of
    $25.41&nbsp;per barrel and $4.20&nbsp;per Mmbtu and weighted
    average New&nbsp;York Mercantile Exchange (&#147;NYMEX&#148;)
    ceiling prices of $26.44&nbsp;per barrel and $4.34&nbsp;per
    Mmbtu, respectively, excluding the effect, if any, of the
    three-way floor price. The remaining 2004 natural gas CPRM
    contract settlements are calculated based on the Northwest
    Pipeline Rocky Mountain Index (&#147;NWPRM&#148;) at a weighted
    average swap price of $3.33&nbsp;per Mmbtu. In addition,
    included in the 71.3&nbsp;Bcf of natural gas contracts are basis
    swaps covering 3.7&nbsp;Bcf of natural gas for 2004 that lock in
    the pricing differential between NYMEX and NWPRM at a weighted
    average price differential of $0.66&nbsp;per Mmbtu and
    9.2&nbsp;Bcf of natural gas for 2004 that lock in the pricing
    differential between NYMEX and Colorado Interstate Gas Index
    (&#147;CIG&#148;) at a weighted average price differential of
    $0.76&nbsp;per Mmbtu.
    </FONT></TD>

    </FONT></TD>

<TR valign="bottom" bgcolor="#EEEEEE">
    <TD colspan="4" align="left" valign="top">
    <DIV style="margin-left:10px; text-indent:-10px">

<P align="left">
<HR size="1" width="18%" align="left" noshade>
<P>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0">

<TR>
    <TD width="4%"></TD>
    <TD width="96%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD><FONT size="2">(1)&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD align="left">
    <FONT size="2">For any particular NYMEX swap sold transaction,
    the Counterparty is required to make a payment to Westport in
    the event that the NYMEX Reference Price for any settlement
    period is less than the swap price for such hedge, and Westport
    is required to make a payment to the Counterparty in the event
    that the NYMEX Reference Price for any settlement period is
    greater than the swap price for such hedge.
    </FONT></TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD><FONT size="2">(2)&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD align="left">
    <FONT size="2">For any particular NWPRM swap sold transaction,
    the Counterparty is required to make a payment to Westport in
    the event that the NWPRM Index Price for any settlement period
    is less than the swap price for such hedge, and Westport is
    required to make a payment to the Counterparty in the event that
    the NWPRM Index Price for any settlement period is greater than
    the swap price for such hedge.
    </FONT></TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD><FONT size="2">(3)&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD align="left">
    <FONT size="2">For any particular NYMEX collar transaction, the
    counterparty is required to make a payment to Westport if the
    average NYMEX Reference Price for the reference period is below
    the floor price for
    </FONT></TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<P align="center"><FONT size="2">F-20
</FONT>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV align="center">
<B><FONT size="2">WESTPORT RESOURCES CORPORATION</FONT></B>
</DIV>

<P align="center">
<B><FONT size="2">NOTES TO CONSOLIDATED
FINANCIAL&nbsp;STATEMENTS&nbsp;&#151;&nbsp;(Continued)</FONT></B>
<P>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0">

<TR>
    <TD width="4%"></TD>
    <TD width="96%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD></TD>
    <TD align="left">
    <FONT size="2">such transaction, and Westport is required to
    make payment to the counterparty if the average NYMEX Reference
    Price is above the ceiling price of such transaction.
    </FONT></TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD><FONT size="2">(4)&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD align="left">
    <FONT size="2">Three way collars are settled as described in
    footnote&nbsp;(3) above, with the following exception: if the
    NYMEX Reference Price falls below the three-way floor price, the
    average floor price is reduced by the amount the NYMEX Reference
    Price is below the three-way floor price. For example, if the
    NYMEX Reference Price is $18.00&nbsp;per bbl during the term of
    the 2004 three-way collars, then the average floor price would
    be $23.13&nbsp;per bbl.
    </FONT></TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD><FONT size="2">(5)&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD align="left">
    <FONT size="2">For any particular basis swap versus NYMEX, the
    counterparty is required to make a payment to Westport in the
    event that the difference between the NYMEX Reference Price and
    the applicable published index (NWPRM or CIG) for any settlement
    period is greater than the swap differential price for such
    hedge, and Westport is required to make a payment to the
    counterparty in the event that the difference between the NYMEX
    Reference Price and the applicable published index (NWPRM or
    CIG) for any settlement period is less than the swap
    differential price for such hedge.
    </FONT></TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">Also see Note&nbsp;7 of the Consolidated
Financial Statements for interest rate hedge disclosures.
</FONT>

<DIV>&nbsp;</DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0">

<TR>
    <TD width="4%"></TD>
    <TD width="96%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD><B><FONT size="2">4.</FONT></B></TD>
    <TD>
    <B><FONT size="2">Earnings Per Share and Other Comprehensive
    Income (Loss)</FONT></B></TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<DIV>&nbsp;</DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0">

<TR>
    <TD width="3%"></TD>
    <TD width="97%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD></TD>
    <TD>
    <B><I><FONT size="2">Earnings per Share</FONT></I></B></TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">Basic earnings per share are computed by dividing
net earnings attributable to common stock by the weighted
average number of common shares outstanding during each period,
excluding treasury shares. Diluted earnings per share are
computed by adjusting the average number of common shares
outstanding for the dilutive effect, if any, of convertible
preferred stock and stock options.
</FONT>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">The following sets forth the calculation of basic
and diluted earnings per share:
</FONT>

<CENTER>
<TABLE width="70%" align="center" cellspacing="0" cellpadding="0" border="0">

    <TD width="66%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="3%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="5%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="1%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="5%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD width="3%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>

    <TD width="5%"><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>

<DIV align="center">
<B><FONT size="2">WESTPORT RESOURCES CORPORATION</FONT></B>
</DIV>

<P align="center">
<B><FONT size="2">NOTES TO CONSOLIDATED
FINANCIAL&nbsp;STATEMENTS&nbsp;&#151;&nbsp;(Continued)</FONT></B>

<DIV>&nbsp;</DIV>

    <TD width="3%"></TD>
    <TD width="97%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD></TD>
    <TD>
    <B><I><FONT size="2">Comprehensive Income (Loss)</FONT></I></B></TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">The Company follows SFAS&nbsp;No.&nbsp;130,
&#147;Reporting Comprehensive Income,&#148; which establishes
standards for reporting comprehensive income. In addition to net
income, comprehensive income includes all changes in equity
during a period, except those resulting from investments and
distributions to the owners of the Company. The components of
other comprehensive income (loss) and related tax effects for
the twelve months ended December&nbsp;31, 2003 and 2002 are as
follows:
</FONT>

<CENTER>
<TABLE width="100%" align="center" cellspacing="0" cellpadding="0" border="0">

<DIV>&nbsp;</DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0">

<TR>
    <TD width="4%"></TD>
    <TD width="96%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD><B><FONT size="2">5.</FONT></B></TD>
    <TD>
    <B><FONT size="2">Concentration of Credit Risk</FONT></B></TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">The Company has accounts with separate banks in
Denver, Colorado, Dallas, Texas and Calgary, Canada. The Company
invests substantially all available cash in overnight investment
accounts consisting of U.S.&nbsp;Treasury obligations and
commercial paper. At December&nbsp;31, 2003, the balance in the
overnight investment accounts was $68.3&nbsp;million.
</FONT>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">The Company sells its oil and natural gas
production to companies it believes to be creditworthy. Actual
losses relating to product sales have been immaterial and
currently the Company does require collateral from certain
companies.
</FONT>

<P align="center"><FONT size="2">F-22
</FONT>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">As of December&nbsp;31, 2003, the Company had net
operating loss carryforwards for income tax purposes of
approximately $71.4&nbsp;million, which expire between 2018 and
2022 and may be utilized to reduce future tax liability of the
Company. The utilization of substantially all of these loss
carryforwards, acquired in the Merger, will be limited to
approximately $16.3&nbsp;million per year.
</FONT>

<DIV>&nbsp;</DIV>

    Subordinated Notes&nbsp;Due 2011 as of December&nbsp;31, 2003
    reflects the aggregate face amount of $700&nbsp;million plus
    $14.2&nbsp;million related to the premium recorded in connection
    with the issuance of 8&nbsp;1/4%&nbsp;Senior Subordinated

<P align="center"><FONT size="2">F-24
</FONT>

<P><HR noshade><P>

<DIV align="center">
<B><FONT size="2">WESTPORT RESOURCES CORPORATION</FONT></B>
</DIV>

<P align="center">
<B><FONT size="2">NOTES TO CONSOLIDATED
FINANCIAL&nbsp;STATEMENTS&nbsp;&#151;&nbsp;(Continued)</FONT></B>
<P>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0">

<TR>
    <TD width="4%"></TD>
    <TD width="96%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD><FONT size="2">(2)&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD align="left">
    <FONT size="2">The balance of the 8&nbsp;1/4%&nbsp;Senior
    Subordinated Notes&nbsp;Due 2011 as of December&nbsp;31, 2002
    reflects an increase of $8.9&nbsp;million related to the premium
    recorded in connection with the issuance of
    8&nbsp;1/4%&nbsp;Senior Subordinated Notes&nbsp;Due 2011 on
    December&nbsp;17, 2002 (see 8&nbsp;1/4%&nbsp;Senior Subordinated
    Notes&nbsp;Due 2011 below) and an increase of $7.9&nbsp;million
    related to fair market value adjustments recorded as a result of
    the Company&#146;s interest rate swaps accounted for as fair
    value hedges. The face amount of the notes at December&nbsp;31,
    2002 was $575.0&nbsp;million. See <I>Interest Rate
    Swaps&nbsp;&#151; Hedges</I> below.
    </FONT></TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD><FONT size="2">(3)&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD align="left">
    <FONT size="2">There was no balance outstanding with respect to
    the 8&nbsp;7/8%&nbsp;Senior Subordinated Notes due 2007 as of
    December&nbsp;31, 2003, since all of these notes were redeemed
    on May&nbsp;5, 2003. The balance of the 8&nbsp;7/8%&nbsp;Senior
    Subordinated Notes due 2007 as of December&nbsp;31, 2002
    reflects an increase of $3.5&nbsp;million related to the gain on
    the cancellation of the fair market value hedge, which was
    amortized until the notes were redeemed on May&nbsp;5, 2003. The
    face amount of the 8&nbsp;7/8%&nbsp;Senior Subordinated Notes
    due 2007 at December&nbsp;31, 2002 was $122.7&nbsp;million. See
    <I>8&nbsp;7/8%&nbsp;Senior Subordinated Notes due 2007</I> below.
    </FONT></TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<DIV>&nbsp;</DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0">

<TR>
    <TD width="3%"></TD>
    <TD width="97%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD></TD>
    <TD>
    <B><I><FONT size="2">Revolving Credit Facility</FONT></I></B></TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">The Company entered into a new credit facility
(as amended from time to time, the &#147;Revolving Credit
Facility&#148;) on December&nbsp;17, 2002 with JPMorgan Chase
Bank and Credit Suisse First Boston Corporation, for a maximum
committed amount of $600&nbsp;million and an initial borrowing
base of approximately $470&nbsp;million. The facility matures on
December&nbsp;16, 2006 and contains covenants and default
provisions customary for similar credit facilities. We made
borrowings under the Revolving Credit Facility to refinance all
outstanding indebtedness under our previous revolving credit
facility and to pay general corporate expenses.
</FONT>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">On October&nbsp;15, 2003, the Revolving Credit
Facility was amended, to increase the borrowing base from
$470&nbsp;million to $500&nbsp;million. The amendment also
eliminated the limit on the outstanding letters of credit,
provided that the amount of letters of credit outstanding on any
date does not exceed the lesser of the aggregate commitments
under the Revolving Credit Facility and the borrowing base then
in effect, or if the borrowing base is not in effect on such
date, the aggregate commitments under the Revolving Credit
Facility. The amendment also increased the basket allowed for
purposes of providing cash collateral from $10&nbsp;million to
$20&nbsp;million and deleted the requirement to file liens on
properties if not rated BB+ and Ba1 at December&nbsp;31, 2003.
</FONT>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">Advances under the Revolving Credit Facility are
in the form of either an ABR loan or a Eurodollar loan. The
interest on an ABR loan is a fluctuating rate based upon the
highest of: (1)&nbsp;the rate of interest announced by JPMorgan
Chase Bank as its prime rate; (2)&nbsp;the secondary market rate
for three-month certificates of deposits plus 1%; or
(3)&nbsp;the Federal funds effective rate plus 0.5%, plus in
each case a margin of 0% to 0.625% based upon the ratio of total
debt to EBITDAX and the ratings of our senior unsecured debt as
issued by Standard and Poor&#146;s Rating Group and Moody&#146;s
Investors Service, Inc. EBITDAX is defined as net income plus
interest expense, income tax expense, and amounts attributable
to depreciation, depletion, exploration, amortization and other
non-cash charges and expenses, but excluding changes in value of
certain hedging instruments and extraordinary or nonrecurring
gains or losses, subject to certain other specified adjustments.
The interest on a Eurodollar loan is a fluctuating rate based
upon the rate at which Eurodollar deposits in the London
interbank market are quoted plus a margin of 1.000% to 1.875%
based upon the ratio of total debt to EBITDAX and the ratings of
our senior unsecured debt as issued by Standard and Poor&#146;s
Rating Group and Moody&#146;s Investors Service, Inc.
</FONT>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">The Revolving Credit Facility contains various
covenants and restrictive provisions including two financial
covenants that require the Company to maintain a current ratio
of not less than 1.0 to 1.0 and a ratio of EBITDAX to
consolidated interest expense for the preceding four consecutive
fiscal quarters of
</FONT>

<P align="center"><FONT size="2">F-25
</FONT>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV align="center">
<B><FONT size="2">WESTPORT RESOURCES CORPORATION</FONT></B>
</DIV>

<P align="center">
<B><FONT size="2">NOTES TO CONSOLIDATED
FINANCIAL&nbsp;STATEMENTS&nbsp;&#151;&nbsp;(Continued)</FONT></B>

<P align="left">
<FONT size="2">not less than 3.0 to 1.0. Commitment fees under
the Revolving Credit Facility range from 0.25% to 0.5% on the
average daily amount of the available unused borrowing capacity
based on the rating of our senior unsecured debt as issued by
Standard and Poor&#146;s Rating Group and Moody&#146;s Investor
Service, Inc.
</FONT>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">As of December&nbsp;31, 2003, we had borrowings
and letters of credit issued of approximately
$335.6&nbsp;million outstanding under the Credit Facility, with
a weighted average interest rate of 2.9% and available unused
borrowing capacity of approximately $164.4&nbsp;million. The
letters of credit were issued primarily in connection with the
margin requirements of the Company&#146;s oil and natural gas
derivative contracts.
</FONT>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">Under the terms of the Revolving Credit Facility
the Company must meet certain tests before it is able to declare
or pay any dividend on (other than dividends payable solely in
equity interests of the Company other than disqualified stock),
or make any payment of, or set apart assets for a sinking or
other analogous fund for the purchase, redemption, defeasance,
retirement or other acquisition of, any shares of any class of
equity interests of the Company or any restricted subsidiary,
whether now or hereafter outstanding, or make any other
distribution in respect thereof, either directly or indirectly,
whether in cash or property or in obligations of the Company or
any restricted subsidiary.
</FONT>

<DIV>&nbsp;</DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0">

<TR>
    <TD width="3%"></TD>
    <TD width="97%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD></TD>
    <TD>
    <B><I><FONT size="2">8&nbsp;1/4%&nbsp;Senior Subordinated
    Notes&nbsp;Due 2011</FONT></I></B></TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">On April&nbsp;3, 2003, the Company issued
$125&nbsp;million in additional principal amount of the
8&nbsp;1/4%&nbsp;Senior Subordinated Notes&nbsp;Due 2011
pursuant to Rule&nbsp;144A and Regulation&nbsp;S under the
Securities Act of 1933 (the &#147;Securities Act&#148;) at a
price of 106% of the principal amount, with accrued interest
from November&nbsp;1, 2002. The 2003 notes were issued as
additional debt securities under the indenture pursuant to
which, on November&nbsp;5, 2001, the Company issued
$275&nbsp;million of 8&nbsp;1/4%&nbsp;Senior Subordinated
Notes&nbsp;Due 2011 and on December&nbsp;17, 2002, the Company
issued $300&nbsp;million of 8&nbsp;1/4%&nbsp;Senior Subordinated
Notes&nbsp;Due 2011. All of the 2001 and 2002 notes were
subsequently exchanged on March&nbsp;14, 2002 and March&nbsp;12,
2003, respectively, for equal principal amounts of notes having
substantially identical terms and registered under the
Securities Act. The proceeds from the 2003 notes were used to
fund the redemption of the Company&#146;s
8&nbsp;7/8%&nbsp;Senior Subordinated Notes due 2007 (described
below) on May&nbsp;5, 2003 and to reduce the indebtedness under
the Revolving Credit Facility. The Company has agreed to file an
exchange offer registration statement, or under certain
circumstances, a shelf registration statement, pursuant to a
registration rights agreement relating to the 2003 notes. On
June&nbsp;4, 2003, the Company filed the exchange offer
registration statement, as amended on September&nbsp;12, 2003
and February&nbsp;5, 2004, relating to the 2003 notes, which was
declared effective by the SEC on February&nbsp;9, 2004. The
Company is currently offering to exchange up to
$125&nbsp;million aggregate principal amount of new
8&nbsp;1/4%&nbsp;Senior Subordinated Notes&nbsp;Due 2011 that
have been registered under the Securities Act for an equal
principal amount of the 2003 notes. The Company expects to
consummate the exchange offer in March of 2004.
</FONT>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">The notes are senior subordinated unsecured
obligations of the Company and are guaranteed on a senior
subordinated basis by some of its existing and future restricted
subsidiaries. The notes mature on November&nbsp;1, 2011. The
Company pays interest on the notes semi-annually on May&nbsp;1
and November&nbsp;1. On November&nbsp;1, 2003, the Company paid
additional interest of 0.5%&nbsp;per annum on the 2003 notes,
which accrued from October&nbsp;1, 2003, and will continue to
pay additional interest, accruing from November&nbsp;1, 2003
until we consummate the exchange offer contemplated in the
exchange offer registration statement. The Company is entitled
to redeem the notes in whole or in part on or after
November&nbsp;1, 2006 for the redemption price set forth in the
notes. Prior to November&nbsp;1, 2006, the Company is entitled
to redeem the notes, in whole but not in part, at a redemption
price equal to the principal amount of the notes plus a premium.
There is no sinking fund for the notes.
</FONT>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">The indenture governing the
8&nbsp;1/4%&nbsp;Senior Subordinated Notes Due 2011 limits the
activity of the Company and its restricted subsidiaries. The
provisions of such indenture limit the ability of the Company
</FONT>

<P align="center"><FONT size="2">F-26
</FONT>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV align="center">
<B><FONT size="2">WESTPORT RESOURCES CORPORATION</FONT></B>
</DIV>

<P align="center">
<B><FONT size="2">NOTES TO CONSOLIDATED
FINANCIAL&nbsp;STATEMENTS&nbsp;&#151;&nbsp;(Continued)</FONT></B>

<P align="left">
<FONT size="2">and its restricted subsidiaries to incur
additional indebtedness; pay dividends on capital stock or
redeem, repurchase or retire such capital stock or subordinated
indebtedness; make investments; incur liens; create any
consensual limitation on the ability of the Company&#146;s
restricted subsidiaries to pay dividends, make loans or transfer
property to the Company; engage in transactions with the
Company&#146;s affiliates; sell assets, including capital stock
of the Company&#146;s subsidiaries; and consolidate, merge or
transfer assets. During any period that these notes have
investment grade ratings from both Moody&#146;s Investors
Service, Inc. and Standard and Poor&#146;s Ratings Group and no
default has occurred and is continuing, the foregoing covenants
will cease to be in effect with the exception of covenants that
contain limitations on liens and on, among other things, certain
consolidations, mergers and transfers of assets. The
8&nbsp;1/4%&nbsp;Senior Subordinated Notes Due 2011 do not
currently qualify as investment grade.
</FONT>

<DIV>&nbsp;</DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0">

<TR>
    <TD width="3%"></TD>
    <TD width="97%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD></TD>
    <TD>
    <B><I><FONT size="2">8&nbsp;7/8%&nbsp;Senior Subordinated Notes
    due 2007</FONT></I></B></TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">In connection with the Merger, the Company
assumed $147&nbsp;million face amount, $149&nbsp;million fair
value, of Belco&#146;s 8&nbsp;7/8%&nbsp;Senior Subordinated
Notes due 2007. On November&nbsp;1, 2001, approximately
$24.3&nbsp;million face amount of these notes was tendered to
the Company pursuant to the change of control provisions of the
related indenture. The tender price was equal to 101% of the
principal amount of each note plus accrued and unpaid interest
as of October&nbsp;29, 2001. Including the premium and accrued
interest, the total amount paid to repay the tendered notes was
$24.8&nbsp;million. The Company used borrowings under its
previous revolving credit facility to fund the repayment. No
gain or loss was recorded in connection with the redemption as
the fair value of the 8&nbsp;7/8%&nbsp;Senior Subordinated Notes
recorded in connection with the Merger equaled the redemption
cost. On May&nbsp;5, 2003, the Company redeemed the remaining
outstanding 8&nbsp;7/8%&nbsp;Senior Subordinated Notes due 2007
in the aggregate principal amount of approximately
$123&nbsp;million. Including the premium and accrued interest,
the total amount paid to redeem these notes was
$129.7&nbsp;million. The redemption was funded with the proceeds
from the offering of $125&nbsp;million aggregate principal
amount of the Company&#146;s 8&nbsp;1/4%&nbsp;Senior
Subordinated Notes&nbsp;Due 2011, issued on April&nbsp;3, 2003.
The remaining proceeds were used to reduce indebtedness under
the Revolving Credit Facility. The Company recorded a
$0.9&nbsp;million loss in connection with the redemption of the
8&nbsp;7/8%&nbsp;Senior Subordinated Notes due 2007.
</FONT>

<DIV>&nbsp;</DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0">

<TR>
    <TD width="3%"></TD>

    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD align="right" valign="bottom" nowrap><FONT size="2">LIBOR + 3.55%</FONT></TD>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD align="left" valign="top">
    <DIV style="margin-left:10px; text-indent:-10px">
    <FONT size="2">$&nbsp;50&nbsp;million
    </FONT></DIV>
    </TD>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD align="center" valign="bottom" nowrap><FONT size="2">January 2003</FONT></TD>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD align="center" valign="bottom" nowrap><FONT size="2">November 1, 2011</FONT></TD>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
    <TD align="right" valign="bottom" nowrap><FONT size="2">LIBOR + 3.42%</FONT></TD>
    <TD><FONT size="2">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>
</CENTER>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">The Company entered into the interest rate swap
contracts above to hedge the fair value of a portion of the
8&nbsp;1/4%&nbsp;Senior Subordinated Notes&nbsp;Due 2011.
Because these swaps meet the conditions to qualify for the
&#147;short cut&#148; method of assessing effectiveness under
the provisions SFAS&nbsp;No.&nbsp;133, the change in the fair
value of the notes is assumed to equal the change in the fair
value of the interest rate swap. As such, there is no
ineffectiveness assumed to exist between the interest rate swap
and the notes.
</FONT>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">The interest rate swaps are fixed for floating
swaps in that the Company receives the fixed rate of 8.25% and
pays the floating rate. The floating rate is redetermined every
six months based on the London Interbank Offered Rate
(&#147;LIBOR&#148;) in effect at the contractual reset date.
When LIBOR plus the applicable margin shown above is less than
8.25%, the Company receives a payment from the counterparty
equal to the difference in rate times the notional amount. When
LIBOR plus the applicable margin shown
</FONT>

<P align="center"><FONT size="2">F-27
</FONT>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV align="center">
<B><FONT size="2">WESTPORT RESOURCES CORPORATION</FONT></B>
</DIV>

<P align="center">
<B><FONT size="2">NOTES TO CONSOLIDATED
FINANCIAL&nbsp;STATEMENTS&nbsp;&#151;&nbsp;(Continued)</FONT></B>

<P align="left">
<FONT size="2">above is greater than 8.25%, the Company pays the
counterparty the difference in rate times the notional amount.
As of December&nbsp;31, 2003, the Company recorded a derivative
asset of $4.7&nbsp;million related to the interest rate swaps,
which have been designated as fair value hedges, with a
corresponding debt increase. Based on the fair value of the
interest rate swaps at December&nbsp;31, 2003, the Company could
expect to receive approximately $0.6&nbsp;million per year
through 2011.
</FONT>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">In September 2002, the Company terminated an
interest rate swap on the 8&nbsp;7/8%&nbsp;Senior Subordinated
Notes due 2007 resulting in the receipt of a $3.7&nbsp;million
fair value gain, which was added to the outstanding balance of
the notes and was amortized until May&nbsp;5, 2003, the date of
redemption of all of the Company&#146;s outstanding
8&nbsp;7/8%&nbsp;Senior Subordinated Notes due 2007. See
<I>8&nbsp;7/8%&nbsp;Senior Subordinated Notes due 2007
</I>discussed above.
</FONT>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">Maturities of long-term debt for each of the five
years following December&nbsp;31, 2003 are as follows (in
thousands):

<TR valign="top">
    <TD><B><FONT size="2">8.</FONT></B></TD>
    <TD>
    <B><FONT size="2">Stockholders&#146; Equity</FONT></B></TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">On December&nbsp;16, 2002, the Company closed the
shelf offering of 11.5&nbsp;million shares of common stock at a
price of $19.90&nbsp;per share, which includes 1.5&nbsp;million
shares covered by an over-allotment option granted to, and which
was exercised by, the underwriters. The Company received net
proceeds of approximately $216&nbsp;million from the sale of our
common stock, which the Company used to finance, in part, the
Uinta Basin Acquisition.
</FONT>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">On November&nbsp;19, 2002, the Company completed
the private equity offering of 3.125&nbsp;million shares of its
common stock to Spindrift Partners, L.P., Spindrift Investors
(Bermuda) L.P., Global Natural Resources&nbsp;III and Global
Natural Resources&nbsp;III L.P. at a net price to us of
$16.00&nbsp;per share for aggregate proceeds of
$50&nbsp;million. On December&nbsp;31, 2002, the Company filed
the shelf registration statement registering the resale by the
selling stockholders from time to time of its common stock
issued in the private equity offering. The registration
statement was declared effective on January&nbsp;7, 2003 by the
SEC.
</FONT>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">On September&nbsp;21, 2001, the Board of
Directors authorized management to repurchase up to
$30&nbsp;million of the Company&#146;s common stock. Through
December&nbsp;31, 2003, the Company has repurchased
30,000&nbsp;shares of its common stock at an average price of
$13.61&nbsp;per share including broker commissions.
</FONT>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">The Company&#146;s 6&nbsp;1/2%&nbsp;convertible
preferred stock has a liquidation preference of $25&nbsp;per
share and is convertible at the option of the holder into shares
of the Company&#146;s common stock at an initial conversion rate
of 0.465795&nbsp;shares of common stock for each share of
preferred stock, equivalent to a conversion price of
$11.64&nbsp;per share of common stock. During 2003, 2002 and
2001, the Company declared and paid dividends of $1.63, $1.63
and $0.54&nbsp;per share of preferred stock, respectively.
</FONT>

<P align="center"><FONT size="2">F-28
</FONT>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD><B><FONT size="2">9.</FONT></B></TD>
    <TD>
    <B><FONT size="2">Stock Options</FONT></B></TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">On October&nbsp;17, 2000, the Westport Resources
Directors&#146; Stock Option Plan and the Westport Resources
Corporation Stock Option Plan (the &#147;Predecessor
Plans&#148;) were merged into the Westport Resources Corporation
2000 Stock Incentive Plan (the &#147;Stock Option Plan&#148;).
The Stock Option Plan provides for issuance of options to
employees, officers and directors to purchase shares of common
stock. The aggregate number of shares of common stock that may
be issued under the Stock Option Plan is 6,232,484&nbsp;shares.
The exercise price, vesting and duration of the options may vary
and will be determined at the time of issuance.
</FONT>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">During 2003, options to purchase
723,350&nbsp;shares of the Company&#146;s common stock were
granted under the Stock Option Plan at exercise prices between
$20.07 and $26.70&nbsp;per share, which reflected the estimated
fair market value of the shares at the date of grant. These
options vest ratably over two or three&nbsp;years from the date
of grant and have a term of 10&nbsp;years.
</FONT>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">During 2002, options to purchase
648,099&nbsp;shares of the Company&#146;s common stock were
granted under the Stock Option Plan at exercise prices between
$17.18 and $20.47&nbsp;per share, which reflected the estimated
fair market value of the shares at the date of grant. These
options vest ratably over two or three years from the date of
grant and have a term of 10&nbsp;years.
</FONT>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">In connection with the August&nbsp;21, 2001
merger of Old Westport and Belco, options previously issued by
Belco were converted into options to purchase
788,194&nbsp;shares of Westport common stock at exercise prices
between $11.82 and $70.30&nbsp;per share. These exercise prices
reflect the estimated fair market value of the shares on
August&nbsp;21, 2001, after converting the Belco options into
the existing Westport plan using a .4125 rate to account for the
reverse stock split which was consummated under the merger
agreement. Since Belco options converted into options to
purchase Westport common stock were fully vested, the fair value
of Westport options issued upon conversion was included in the
purchase price of the Merger, in accordance with FASB
Interpretation No.&nbsp;44 (see Note&nbsp;2&nbsp;&#151; Belco
Merger). The fair value of Westport options issued upon
conversion of Belco options was determined using the
Black-Scholes option pricing model. Also during 2001, options to
purchase 690,562&nbsp;shares of the Company&#146;s common stock
were granted under the Stock Option Plan at exercise prices
between $15.90 and $31.07&nbsp;per share, which reflected the
estimated fair market value of the shares at the date of grant.
The options vest ratably over two or three&nbsp;years from the
date of grant and have a term of 10&nbsp;years.
</FONT>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">In March 2000, the FASB issued Interpretation
No.&nbsp;44, &#147;Accounting for Certain Transactions Involving
Stock Compensation.&#148; The Interpretation clarified
(a)&nbsp;the definition of employee for purposes of applying APB
Opinion No.&nbsp;25, (b)&nbsp;the criteria for determining
whether a plan qualifies as a noncompensatory plan, (c)&nbsp;the
accounting consequence of various modifications to the terms of
previously fixed stock options or awards, and (d)&nbsp;the
accounting for an exchange of stock options and/or awards in a
business combination. Under provisions of the Interpretation,
the Company is required to account for 1,080,473 of replacement
options, for options repurchased by the Company on
March&nbsp;24, 2000, as variable awards from July&nbsp;1, 2000
until the date the options are exercised, forfeited or expire
unexercised. Compensation cost will be measured for the amount
of any increases in our stock price after July&nbsp;1, 2000 and
recognized over the remaining vesting period of the options. Any
decreases in the Company stock price subsequent to July&nbsp;1,
2000 will be recognized as a decrease in compensation cost,
limited to the amount of compensation cost previously recognized
as a result of increases in our stock price. Any adjustment to
compensation cost for further changes in the stock price after
the award vests will be recognized immediately. As of
December&nbsp;31, 2003, 856,065 of the replacement options were
still outstanding, which resulted in $7.6&nbsp;million,
$4.3&nbsp;million and $0.4&nbsp;million of compensation costs
recorded in 2003, 2002 and 2001, respectively.
</FONT>

<P align="center"><FONT size="2">F-29
</FONT>

Accounting Principles Board Opinion No.&nbsp;25,
&#147;Accounting for Stock Issued to Employees,&#148; and has
elected to adopt the disclosure provisions of
SFAS&nbsp;No.&nbsp;148, &#147;Accounting for Stock-Based

compensation costs for the Company&#146;s options been
determined based on the fair value at the grant dates

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">The weighted average fair value of options
granted during the years ended December&nbsp;31, 2003, 2002 and
2001, calculated using the Black-Scholes option pricing model,
was $8.29, $8.45 and $8.88, respectively. The fair value of each
option granted is estimated with the following weighted average
assumptions for grants in 2003, 2002 and 2001: risk-free
interest rate of 1.13%, 1.67% and 3.89%, respectively; no
dividend yields; expected volatility of 44.62%, 52.22% and
40.74%, respectively; and expected lives of five years.
</FONT>

    <TD>
    <B><FONT size="2">Restricted Stock Awards</FONT></B></TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">Common stock shares issued to certain employees
as restricted stock awards pursuant to the Company&#146;s 2000
Stock Incentive Plan were 158,100 and 36,550 for the years ended
December&nbsp;31, 2003 and 2001, respectively. There were no
restricted stock awards issued for the year ended
December&nbsp;31, 2002. The shares are restricted for various
periods ranging from one to three years after the date of grant.
As of December&nbsp;31, 2003, 32,550&nbsp;shares had vested. As
of December&nbsp;31, 2003, 11,400&nbsp;shares were cancelled for
certain terminated employees. During the years ended
December&nbsp;31, 2003, 2002 and 2001 compensation expense of
$0.1&nbsp;million, $0.3&nbsp;million and $0.3&nbsp;million,
respectively, was recorded as a result of the issuances.
</FONT>

</DIV>

<P align="center">

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">Rent expense for the years ended
December&nbsp;31, 2003, 2002 and 2001 was approximately
$1,641,000, $1,439,000 and $954,000, respectively.
</FONT>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">The Company entered into employment agreements on
April&nbsp;1, 2002 with its chief executive officer and
president, which provide for annual base salaries of $382,000
and $264,000, respectively, subject to annual adjustments
through May&nbsp;31, 2005. The agreements provide for severance
payments equal to three times the individual&#146;s then
applicable base salary and three&nbsp;times the average of the
bonus the individual received in the last three&nbsp;years if
the Company terminates such person&#146;s employment other than
for cause or if such person&#146;s employment is terminated upon
a change of control of Westport.
</FONT>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">Following the Merger, the Company entered into
retention agreements with its executive officers. The retention
agreements set forth the terms and conditions of the
officers&#146; compensation in the event of termination of their
employment following a change in control, as defined in the
agreements, within five&nbsp;years of the date of such retention
agreements. Each agreement automatically expires if a change in
control has not occurred within the five-year period, and may be
renewed for successive one-year periods by written agreement of
the parties. If a termination following a change in control
occurs within the specified period, other than a termination for
cause or with good reason, as defined in the agreement, the
terminated person will be entitled to all earned and accrued
compensation and benefits plus severance compensation equal to a
stated percentage of the sum of their respective base salary and
average bonus for three prior years, plus the amount of any
excise tax imposed on such severance payment. In addition, all
equity incentive awards become immediately vested.
</FONT>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">Westport Oil and Gas Company, L.P., the
Company&#146;s wholly-owned subsidiary, is a defendant in a case
brought in July 2001 against its predecessor, Belco Energy
Corp., in the district court of Sweetwater County, Wyoming. The
complaint seeks damages on behalf of a purported class of
royalty owners for alleged improper deduction, valuation and
reporting under the Wyoming Royalty Payment Act in connection
with royalty payments made by Belco on production from wells it
operates in the Moxa Arch area of the Green River Basin. During
initial stages of the case, plaintiffs have advised Westport
that they calculate the amount of damages allegedly owed by
Belco as approximately $1,165,000, which includes attorneys fees
and litigation costs. Westport has denied liability for any of
these damages and believes that it has valid defenses to
plaintiffs&#146; claims. Class certification and discovery have
been stayed pending the decision by the Wyoming Supreme Court in
a case involving unrelated parties that may have a bearing on
this case and other similar cases filed by plaintiffs against
other oil and gas industry operators in the Green River Basin.
Settlement discussions have occurred with plaintiffs and are
ongoing. The Company believes that the potential liability with
respect to such proceedings is not material in the aggregate to
the
</FONT>

<P align="center"><FONT size="2">F-32
</FONT>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV align="center">
<B><FONT size="2">WESTPORT RESOURCES CORPORATION</FONT></B>
</DIV>

<P align="center">
<B><FONT size="2">NOTES TO CONSOLIDATED
FINANCIAL&nbsp;STATEMENTS&nbsp;&#151;&nbsp;(Continued)</FONT></B>

<P align="left">
<FONT size="2">Company&#146;s financial position, results of
operations or cash flows. Accordingly, the Company has not
established a reserve for loss in connection with this
proceeding.
</FONT>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">The Company is subject to governmental and
regulatory controls arising in the ordinary course of business.
It is the opinion of the Company&#146;s management that there
are no claims or litigation involving the Company that are
likely to have a material adverse effect on its financial
position, results of operations or cash flows.
</FONT>

<DIV>&nbsp;</DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0">

<TR>
    <TD width="5%"></TD>
    <TD width="95%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD><B><FONT size="2">13.</FONT></B></TD>
    <TD>
    <B><FONT size="2">Retirement Savings Plan</FONT></B></TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">Effective December&nbsp;1, 1995, the Company
adopted a retirement savings plan. The Westport Savings and
Profit Sharing Plan (the &#147;Plan&#148;) is a defined
contribution plan and covers all employees of the Company. The
Plan is subject to the provisions of the Employee Retirement
Income Security Act of 1974, as amended, and Section&nbsp;401(k)
of the Internal Revenue Code.
</FONT>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">The assets of the Plan are held and the related
investments are executed by the Plan&#146;s trustee.
Participants in the Plan have investment alternatives in which
to place their funds and may place their funds in one or more of
these investment alternatives. Administrative fees are paid by
the Company on behalf of the Plan. The Plan provides for
discretionary matching by the Company of 75% of each
participant&#146;s contributions up to 6% of the
participant&#146;s compensation. The Company contributed
$894,000, $657,000 and $400,000 for the years ended
December&nbsp;31, 2003, 2002 and 2001, respectively.
</FONT>

<DIV>&nbsp;</DIV>

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0">

<TR>
    <TD width="5%"></TD>
    <TD width="95%"></TD>
</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD><B><FONT size="2">14.</FONT></B></TD>
    <TD>
    <B><FONT size="2">Segment Information</FONT></B></TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">The Company operates in four geographic
divisions: Northern (Rocky Mountains); Southern (Permian Basin,
Mid-Continent and Gulf Coast); Western (Uinta Basin) and Gulf of
Mexico (offshore). Amounts presented below for Western only
represent fifteen days of operations in 2002. All four areas are
engaged in the production, development, acquisition and
exploration of oil and natural gas properties. The Company
evaluates segment performance based on the profit or loss from
operations before income taxes.
</FONT>

<P align="center"><FONT size="2">F-33

    joint interest billing receivables at December&nbsp;31, 2003,
    2002 and 2001. Because the Company tracks its joint interest
    receivables by joint interest partner and not by property, the
    Company is unable to allocate joint interest receivables to its
    three divisions.

</TR>

<TR valign="top">
    <TD><B><FONT size="2">15.</FONT></B></TD>
    <TD>
    <B><FONT size="2">Condensed Consolidated Financial Statements of
    Subsidiary Guarantors:</FONT></B></TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>

<P align="left">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<FONT size="2">On April&nbsp;3, 2003 the Company issued
$125&nbsp;million of its 8&nbsp;1/4%&nbsp;Senior Subordinated
Notes&nbsp;Due 2011. These notes were issued as additional debt
securities under an indenture, pursuant to which, on
November&nbsp;5, 2001 the Company issued $275&nbsp;million of
8&nbsp;1/4%&nbsp;Senior Subordinated Notes&nbsp;Due 2011 and on
December&nbsp;17, 2002, the Company issued $300&nbsp;million of
8&nbsp;1/4%&nbsp;Senior Subordinated Notes&nbsp;Due 2011. All of
the 8&nbsp;1/4%&nbsp;Senior Subordinated Notes&nbsp;Due 2011 are
jointly and severally guaranteed, on a senior subordinated
unsecured basis, by the following wholly-owned subsidiaries of
Westport: Westport Finance Co., Jerry Chambers Exploration
Company, Westport Argentina LLC, Westport Canada LLC, Westport
Oil and Gas Company, L.P., Horse Creek Trading&nbsp;&#38;
Compression Company LLC, Westport Field Services, LLC, Westport
Overriding Royalty LLC, WHG, Inc. and WHL, Inc. (collectively,
the &#147;Subsidiary Guarantors&#148;). The guarantees of the
Subsidiary Guarantors are subordinated to senior debt of the
Subsidiary Guarantors.
</FONT>

<P align="center"><FONT size="2">F-35
</FONT>

<TR>
    <TD colspan="20" align="center" valign="top">
    <B><FONT size="2">LIABILITIES AND STOCKHOLDERS&#146;
    EQUITY</FONT></B></TD>
</TR>
